title: Emphasis & Fronting
description: Слушайте конструкции эмфатического выделения и вынесения.

tasks.audioText: The negotiations had stalled for weeks. It was the junior diplomat who eventually broke the deadlock with a creative compromise.
tasks.transcript: It was the junior diplomat who eventually broke the deadlock with a creative compromise.

options.text: A senior official resolved the impasse.
The young diplomat was the one who finally resolved the stalemate through an inventive solution.
The negotiations ended without any agreement.
The deadlock was caused by the junior diplomat.

tasks.explanation: 'It was X who...' is a cleft sentence that emphasizes the agent. The focus is on the junior diplomat as the person who resolved the situation.

tasks.audioText: Many dismissed her early research as impractical. What she actually discovered was a groundbreaking method for synthesizing renewable fuel.
tasks.transcript: What she actually discovered was a groundbreaking method for synthesizing renewable fuel.

options.text: Her discovery turned out to be a revolutionary technique for producing sustainable fuel.
She never made any significant discoveries.
Her research was exactly as impractical as people thought.
She discovered a new type of fossil fuel.

tasks.explanation: 'What she actually discovered was...' is a pseudo-cleft sentence that emphasizes the discovery. The focus is on the significance of the finding.

tasks.audioText: Critics claimed the director had lost his creative vision. He did produce his most acclaimed film just two years later.
tasks.transcript: He did produce his most acclaimed film just two years later.

options.text: He never directed another successful film.
Contrary to criticism, he genuinely created his best-received movie shortly afterwards.
The critics were right about his decline.
He retired from filmmaking entirely.

tasks.explanation: 'Did produce' uses emphatic 'do' in past tense to contradict the critics' claim. Despite doubts, he achieved his greatest success.

tasks.audioText: The company had strict security policies. Under no circumstances should employees share their access credentials with third parties.
tasks.transcript: Under no circumstances should employees share their access credentials with third parties.

options.text: Employees are absolutely prohibited from giving their login details to outsiders.
Employees can share passwords in emergencies.
The security policy has been relaxed recently.
Third parties already have access to all credentials.

tasks.explanation: 'Under no circumstances' is a fronted negative adverbial causing subject-auxiliary inversion. It expresses an absolute prohibition.

tasks.audioText: The author had been writing for decades without recognition. It was not until her seventh novel that she finally gained international acclaim.
tasks.transcript: It was not until her seventh novel that she finally gained international acclaim.

options.text: She became famous with her very first book.
She only achieved worldwide recognition when she published her seventh book.
She never achieved any recognition at all.
Her seventh novel was a commercial failure.

tasks.explanation: 'It was not until X that...' is a cleft construction emphasizing the timing. The seventh novel was the turning point for her career.

tasks.audioText: The athletes had trained relentlessly for the championship. Never before had the team performed with such extraordinary precision and unity.
tasks.transcript: Never before had the team performed with such extraordinary precision and unity.

options.text: The team always performed this well.
This was the team's worst performance ever.
The team achieved an unprecedented level of accuracy and teamwork.
The team decided not to compete in the championship.

tasks.explanation: 'Never before had...' fronts the negative adverb causing inversion. It emphasizes that this level of performance was historically unmatched.

tasks.audioText: People assumed the merger would fail. What the CEO did was restructure the entire management hierarchy to ensure seamless integration.
tasks.transcript: What the CEO did was restructure the entire management hierarchy to ensure seamless integration.

options.text: The CEO's action was to completely reorganize the leadership structure for smooth unification.
The CEO ignored the merger entirely.
The management hierarchy stayed exactly the same.
The merger failed as people predicted.

tasks.explanation: 'What X did was...' is a pseudo-cleft emphasizing the action taken. The CEO's specific response was a comprehensive restructuring.

tasks.audioText: The historian challenged popular narratives about the revolution. Not only did the uprising lack popular support, but it was also funded by foreign interests.
tasks.transcript: Not only did the uprising lack popular support, but it was also funded by foreign interests.

options.text: The revolution had both widespread support and domestic funding.
The revolution was popular but poorly funded.
The uprising was both unpopular and financially backed by foreign powers.
The historian praised the revolution enthusiastically.

tasks.explanation: 'Not only did X..., but also...' fronts the negative correlative conjunction causing inversion. It emphasizes two negative aspects of the uprising.

tasks.audioText: The orchestra rehearsed tirelessly before the premiere. Particularly impressive was the cellist's interpretation of the second movement.
tasks.transcript: Particularly impressive was the cellist's interpretation of the second movement.

options.text: The cellist's performance of the second movement stood out as especially remarkable.
The cellist performed poorly during rehearsal.
The second movement was cut from the programme.
All musicians performed equally well.

tasks.explanation: Fronting the complement 'Particularly impressive' before 'was' emphasizes the exceptional quality of the cellist's performance.

tasks.audioText: Many doubted the new policy would succeed. The minister does believe that the reforms will yield measurable results within a year.
tasks.transcript: The minister does believe that the reforms will yield measurable results within a year.

options.text: The minister has no confidence in the reforms.
Despite scepticism, the minister genuinely has faith that the changes will produce tangible outcomes soon.
The reforms have already failed.
Results are expected in ten years at the earliest.

tasks.explanation: 'Does believe' uses emphatic 'do' in present tense to counter the doubt. The minister's conviction is being stressed.

tasks.audioText: The surgeon prepared meticulously for the complex procedure. Only after consulting three specialists did she proceed with the operation.
tasks.transcript: Only after consulting three specialists did she proceed with the operation.

options.text: She began the surgery without consulting anyone.
She went ahead with the operation only once she had sought advice from three experts.
The specialists told her to cancel the surgery.
She consulted specialists after completing the operation.

tasks.explanation: 'Only after X did she...' fronts the restrictive adverbial causing inversion. The surgery happened only after triple consultation.

tasks.audioText: The architect faced criticism for the unconventional design. It was the building's environmental efficiency that ultimately silenced the critics.
tasks.transcript: It was the building's environmental efficiency that ultimately silenced the critics.

options.text: The critics continued to oppose the design.
The building's eco-friendly performance was what finally won over the doubters.
The building was demolished due to criticism.
The architect abandoned the unconventional design.

tasks.explanation: 'It was X that...' is a cleft sentence emphasizing the specific quality that changed minds. Environmental efficiency was the deciding factor.

tasks.audioText: The company had invested heavily in cybersecurity. Rarely does a breach of this magnitude go undetected for so long.
tasks.transcript: Rarely does a breach of this magnitude go undetected for so long.

options.text: Large security breaches are commonly missed for extended periods.
It is very uncommon for such a significant security breach to remain hidden for this duration.
The breach was detected immediately.
No security breach actually occurred.

tasks.explanation: 'Rarely does...' fronts the frequency adverb causing inversion. It emphasizes how unusual it is for such a major breach to evade detection.

tasks.audioText: The volunteers worked through the night after the earthquake. So dedicated were they that not a single person left before every survivor had been rescued.
tasks.transcript: So dedicated were they that not a single person left before every survivor had been rescued.

options.text: Most volunteers left early because they were exhausted.
No survivors were found after the earthquake.
Their commitment was so strong that every volunteer stayed until all survivors were saved.
The volunteers arrived the following morning.

tasks.explanation: 'So dedicated were they that...' fronts the adjective complement with inversion for dramatic emphasis on their extraordinary devotion.

tasks.audioText: The experiment had failed repeatedly. Little did the researchers know that their next attempt would revolutionize the entire field of genetics.
tasks.transcript: Little did the researchers know that their next attempt would revolutionize the entire field of genetics.

options.text: The researchers were fully aware of the upcoming breakthrough.
The researchers had no idea that their following experiment would transform genetics completely.
The researchers decided to abandon genetics altogether.
The experiment continued to fail without any progress.

tasks.explanation: 'Little did X know...' fronts the negative adverb for dramatic irony. The researchers were unaware of the historic significance of their next experiment.
